content.description:
The moves are better than the rock itself, which tends toward gritty.

This is the low-angle crack system prominent on the Bilbo Buttress, leaning left and jumping between the 3 crack systems along its way. Starting from the ground, one can use the various cracks to make a B-line for the anchors on El Chivo, and bring up your second.

Not a bad line, but no distination, for sure.
content.protection: A standrad rack. The route is probably PG, because a few palcements are a little tricky and there is some flaky/gritty rock to avoid.

climbs.name: Val De Mello
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Cyndie Bransford, Doug Zeissner & John Thackray, December 1989

content.description: OK, maybe it was just me, but I thought this line was hard for its given grade of 10b. Around to the right of Bilbo Buttress, one can find this short line of bolts, centered on an tiny, odd, 'ramp' feature near the climb's base. Climb up and onto this and beyond. The crux was a weird combination of balance and friction that was a little unpleasant for a J-tree warm up or welcome, and felt sandbagged. None the less, the climb had merit in teaching what is possible on that rock compared to what I am used to in other areas.
content.protection: 4 bolts, bolted anchor/rap  (Watch the first clip!)

climbs.name: Sean Penn
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Chris Baumann, January 2016

content.description:
This is a tightly bolted sport climb located just right of Val de Mello, with an interesting mix of delicate and strenuous movement.

Sean Penn meets El Chapo at a 2-bolt anchor.
content.protection:
6 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.

VARIATION:

From the 6th bolt move left and up to the last bolt of Val de Mello for a slightly longer pitch (7 bolts total).
content.location: Located on the right end of the Bilbo Buttresses, on a small tower/pillar.

climbs.name: El Chivo
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Grant Hiskes, Derek Reinig, Steven Powers

content.description:
Good protection with fun moves make this a worthwhile addition to the area - especially on those cold and windy days that can get your goat.

A small cam (0.5 inch) can be placed before the first bolt and additional pro (2-2.5 inches) is possible after the last bolt if desired. The climb has been done on top-rope straight up from the first bolt at 5.10+ as well.
content.protection: 4 bolts, anchors (all 3/8"); optional gear to 2.5 inches
content.location:
Located in the small cove directly behind (east of) Billboard buttress and 40 feet left of the route

White Trash

.

climbs.name: El Chapo
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Chris Baumann, January 2016

content.description:
Climb the south buttress of the pillar starting 30 feet down and right right from Sean Penn.

El Chapo meets Sean Penn at the 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: On the far right end of the Bilbo Butresses, on a small pillar/tower.

content.description: Another short easy crack - hands and fists.
content.location:
Located 12 feet left of

Debbie Does Everyone

.

content.description: This is a straight in hand crack.
content.location:
Located 20 feet left of

Debbie Does Donuts

.

content.description: This route is not bad, but it's too short to be very good. Maybe it has some merit as a way of getting to the top of the rock to establish a TR on Val De Mello?  In any case, out on the far right end of the Bilbo Buttress, there is a notch between the end towers. In that nothch, on the right hand side there is a hand and fist crack, should you scramble up to it (or just scramble up it). One can scramble off or retreat from anchors above Val De Mello.
content.protection: A set of cams or a few hexes in the larger sizes

content.description:
Another so-so climb on a so-so wall, but if you are there and a completist, do it. Maybe on TR?

The line sports a single bolt a little way up. My notes are thin on this one...
content.protection: Trad rack with thin pro. Caution merited. I TR'd the line having no idea of the difficulty.
content.location: Just left of White Trash there is a single bolt at a seam, to the right of El Chivo.
